revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{BLP sources|date=November 2017}} {{cite check|date=November 2017}}}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2018}} {{Infobox YouTube personality | name = Lilly Singh | image = Lilly Singh by Gage Skidmore.jpg | caption = Singh at [[VidCon]] 2014 | channel_name = IISuperwomanII | views = 2.7 billion | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1988|09|26}}{{cite web|title=Why Birthdays Are Stressful!|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iKeOljPdshk}} | birth_place = [[Scarborough, Toronto|Scarborough]], [[Ontario]], [[Canada]] |height={{height|ft=5|in=5}}{{Citation|last=IISuperwomanII|title=50 Random Things About Me|date=6 August 2013|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nrXdEoUl2Q8&t=158|accessdate=26 February 2017}} | nationality = [[Canadians|Canadian]] | education = [[York University]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]]) | residence = [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], U.S. | occupation = {{flatlist| * YouTuber * Actress * Motivational Speaker * Model * Rapper/Singer * Vlogger * Dancer * Comedian}} | religion = | spouse = | website = {{URL|www.lillysingh.com}} | pseudonym = IISuperwomanII | years active = 2010–present | genre = comedy * [[Comedy]] * [[Vlogging|vlogs]] * [[Sketch comedy|skits]] * rants * [[Motivational speaker|motivation]] | subscribers = 14 million | net worth = $16million | network = [[Studio 71]]
Sarah Weichel Management | associated_acts = | gold_year = 2013 | diamond_year = 2016 | silver_button = yes | gold_button = yes | diamond_button = yes }} '''Lilly Singh''' (born 26 September 1988) is a [[Canadians|Canadian]] YouTuber of [[Indian people|Indian]] descent widely known as '''IISuperwomanII'''. Since beginning her channel in October 2010, her videos have received over 2 billion views, and her channel has accumulated over 14 million subscribers.{{cite web| url=http://www.americanbazaaronline.com/2015/08/10/meet-superwoman-lilly-singh-biggest-youtube-star-of-indian-origin/| title=Meet Superwoman Lilly Singh, biggest YouTube star of Indian origin| last1= Ismail| first1=Ferris| date=10 August 2015| publisher=American Bazar| access-date=17 September 2015}}{{cite web| url=https://subscribercount.live/channel?user=IISuperwomanII| title= IISuperWomanII Live Subscribers| date=18 June 2017| publisher=Live Subs}} In 2017, she was ranked tenth on the ''[[Forbes]]'' list of the world's highest paid YouTube stars, earning a reported [[United States dollar|$]]10.5 million in 2017.{{cite news|title=The World's Highest-Paid YouTube Stars 2017: 10. Lilly Singh|url=https://www.forbes.com/pictures/5a275d6931358e286471a7e8/10-lilly-singh/|accessdate=26 February 2018|work=Forbes}} Singh has featured in the annual [[YouTube Rewind]] every year since 2014.{{cite web|author1=Mangala Dilip|title=Watch YouTube Rewind: Turn Down for 2014 Video Looks Back on Viral Trends, People, Music of Last Year|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.in/watch-youtube-rewind-turn-down-2014-video-looks-back-viral-trends-people-music-last-year-616717#wIyPvwj7jDchjYjw.97|website=International Business Times|accessdate=23 July 2016|date=10 December 2014}}{{cite web|author1=Casey Lewis|title=YouTube's 2015 Year in Rewind Video Will Make the Last 365 Days Flash Before Your Eyes|url=http://www.teenvogue.com/story/youtubes-2015-rewind-video-cameron-dallas-lilly-singh|website=Teen Vogue|publisher=Condé Nast Digital|accessdate=23 July 2016|date=10 December 2015}} She was ranked first on 2017 Forbes Top Influencers List in the entertainment category.{{cite news|last1=O'Connor|first1=Clare|title=Forbes Top Influencers: How YouTuber Lilly Singh Is Going Mainstream – And Making Millions|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/clareoconnor/2017/06/20/forbes-top-influencers-lilly-singh-superwoman-youtube/#1cea120e33e7|publisher=[[Forbes.com]]|date=20 June 2017}} Lilly Singh has received an [[MTV Fandom Awards|MTV Fandom Award]], four [[Streamy Awards]], two [[Teen Choice Awards]] and a [[People's Choice Award]] to date in her career. In 2016, Singh released a red lipstick, in conjunction with Smashbox, called "BAWSE", and released her first feature film, titled ''[[A Trip to Unicorn Island]]''. She reached 14 million YouTube subscribers in August 2018, and her channel is currently in the top 100 most subscribed on YouTube. As of August 2018, she has over 7.8 million followers on [[Instagram]]. In March 2017, she released her first book, ''How to be a Bawse: A Guide to Conquering Life''.{{cite web|url=http://www.lillysinghbook.com/|title=Lilly Singh – Lilly Singh|website=www.lillysinghbook.com|language=en-US|access-date=8 February 2017}} ==Early life== Lilly Singh was born and raised in [[Scarborough, Ontario]]. Her parents, Malwinder and Sukhwinder Singh,{{cite web|author=nurun.com |url=http://www.toronto24hours.ca/2016/02/18/lilly-singh-is-truly-superwoman |title=Lilly Singh is truly Superwoman | 24 Hours Toronto |publisher=Toronto24hours.ca |date=18 February 2016 |accessdate=7 April 2017}} are originally from [[Punjab, India]], and she was raised as a [[Sikh]]. She has an older sister named Tina.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC5cdO1UKWYO_k0evsXohIIA|title=Neurotic Mom Diaries|website=YouTube|access-date=12 May 2016}} As a child, Singh has said she was a [[tomboy]].{{cite news|title=How three local comics found global fame| url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/toronto/how-three-local-comics-found-global-fame/article4107501/|accessdate=2 July 2014|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|date=13 April 2012}} She attended Mary Shadd Public School during her elementary years and in 2006, she graduated from [[Lester B. Pearson Collegiate Institute]].{{cite news| last=Persaud| first=Devin|title=My Roots- Outstanding Student of the Season|url=http://www.my-roots.ca/cms/wp-content/uploads/2010/10/SUMMER-2008-MY-ROOTS.pdf| work=My Roots|accessdate=5 November 2014}} In 2010, she graduated from [[York University]] with a [[Bachelor of Arts]] in Psychology.{{cite web|title='Superwoman' Lilly Singh: From York grad to international YouTube star|url=http://advancement.yorku.ca/2015/01/18/lilly-singh-lol/|publisher=[[York University]]|accessdate=24 February 2018|date=18 January 2015}} Singh developed a strong connection with her [[Punjabi culture|Punjabi heritage]] during visits to [[India]].{{cite web|last=Talwar|first=lolzersVidushi|title=The chic Sikh chick|url=https://in.news.yahoo.com/the-chic-sikh-chick.html| publisher=[[Yahoo!]]|accessdate=2 July 2014|date=25 June 2012}} She struggled with depression, and began making YouTube videos as a way of dealing with her feelings.{{cite web|title=Lilly Singh: How battling Depression Turned YouTuber Lilly Singh Into a Superstar|url=http://www.people.com/article/lilly-singh-youtube-depression| date=13 November 2015|accessdate=15 December 2015|website=People.com|publisher=Time Inc.}} As a young adult, she lived with her parents in [[Markham, Ontario]], and in December 2015, she moved to Los Angeles to further her career.{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/2682337/lilly-singh-iisuperwomanii-youtube-move-los-angeles/|title=Lilly Singh's First-Ever Apartment Puts Your Place To Shame|website=MTV News|access-date=8 March 2016}} ==Career== ===YouTube=== In October 2010, Singh started a YouTube channel under the pseudonym "IISuperwomanII". She has explained that the name ''Superwoman'' was prompted by a childhood idea that she had an invisible "S" on her chest, making her believe she can do anything. Punjabi culture is frequently portrayed in her videos, which also contain satirical takes on everyday life and people's favorite complaints.{{cite news|last = Borges|first = Andre|title = YouTube star Lilly Singh aka 'Superwoman' – The Tina Fey of Punjabis|url = http://www.dnaindia.com/mumbai/report-youtube-star-lilly-singh-aka-superwoman-the-tina-fey-of-punjabis-1965763|accessdate=2 July 2014|work = [[Daily News and Analysis]]|date = 28 February 2014}} Her most popular video is ''How Girls Get Ready'' and her most popular series features her fictional parents, Paramjeet and Manjeet, both played by Singh herself, reacting to trending and controversial videos.{{cite web|last=Patel|first=Arti|title=Lilly Singh Superwoman: YouTube Comedians Take on White people and Indian music is hilarious|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2013/11/22/lilly-singh-superwoman-youtube_n_4324905.html| work=The Huffington Post|accessdate=2 July 2014|date=22 November 2013}}{{cite news|last=Cormack|first=Lucy|title=Lilly Singh is YouTube's Superwoman|url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/lilly-singh-is-youtubes-superwoman-20140530-zrtag.html|accessdate=2 July 2014|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=30 May 2014}} She also frequently collaborates with celebrities on her videos, including [[Dwayne Johnson]], [[Selena Gomez]], [[Seth Rogen]], [[James Franco]], [[Noah Schnapp]], [[Priyanka Chopra]], [[Shay Mitchell]], [[Amber Rose]], [[Steve Aoki]] and [[Caleb McLaughlin]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2016/07/lilly-singh-internet-firsts|title=Superwoman on the Rise: Meet Lilly Singh|date=11 July 2016|last=Bradley|first=Laura|work=HWD|access-date=5 November 2017|language=en}} As of August 2018, she had 14 million+ subscribers who follow her and 2.7 billion views on her main YouTube channel (IISuperwomanII).{{Cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/lifestyle/living/2017/0405/865411-the-feminist-youtuber-you-need-to-know/|title=The Feminist Youtuber You Need To Know|last=Hartmann|first=Jeannine|date=5 April 2017|work=RTE.ie|access-date=11 April 2017|language=en}} ====Vlog Channel==== In December 2011, Singh created a second channel called SuperwomanVlogs, where she chronicles her daily activities and includes behind the scenes footage from her videos. She used it as a second channel to upload videos until August 2014, when she began uploading daily vlogs. Singh has been uploading daily vlogs ever since. As of August 2018, "SuperwomanVlogs" has over 2.6+ million subscribers and 362+ million views. ===Music=== In August 2013, Singh featured alongside [[Jassi Sidhu]] in his Punjabi song ''Hipshaker''. Singh [[Rapping|rapped]] in the song ''Mauj Ki Malharein'', which played in the [[Bollywood]] drama ''[[Gulaab Gang]]'' in August 2014.{{cite web|title=Mauj Ki Malharein (Gulaab Gang)|url=http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/more/videos/view/id/2427757|publisher=[[Bollywood Hungama]]|accessdate=5 November 2014}} In July of the same year, she released a song titled ''#LEH'' in a collaboration with her friend, author and rapper [[Kanwer Singh]], who is known by the pseudonym "Humble the Poet".{{cite news|title=#LEH – Superwoman & Humble The Poet video out now|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/punjabi/music/LEH--Superwoman-Humble-The-Poet-video-out-now/articleshow/37621828.cms|accessdate=2 July 2014|work=[[The Times of India]]|date=2 July 2014}} She recorded and released another music video in February 2015 titled ''The Clean Up Anthem'' in collaboration with Canadian artist Sickick.{{cite web|title=Lily Singh a.k.a Superwoman's New Anthem Will Make you Want to Clean Your Room| url=http://www.browngirlmagazine.com/2015/02/lily-singh-a-k-a-superwomans-new-anthem-will-make-you-want-to-clean-your-room-literally/| publisher=Brown Girl Magazine|accessdate=24 February 2015}} In April 2015, Singh released a song about her hometown Toronto in collaboration with Humble the Poet titled ''#IVIVI'' (roman numerals for 416, Toronto's area code).{{cite news|title=Superwoman And Humble The Poet Show Toronto Pride In #IVIVI Music Video|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2015/04/16/superwoman-humble-the-poet-ivivi_n_7083820.html|publisher=The Huffington Post|accessdate=16 April 2015}} On 8 August 2016, Singh released a visual music piece on YouTube, titled "Voices". The piece includes five songs portraying the "voices in her head". The piece has a genre of Pop/Modern Hip Hop. The songs included are a mix showing signs of boasting, fear of loneliness, lust, goofiness, and positive views promoting global peace.{{citation needed|date=June 2017}}. She also appeared in [[Maroon 5]]'s music video for "[[Girls Like You]]" in May 2018. ===Acting=== Singh appeared as a background dancer in the movies ''[[Speedy Singhs (2011 film)|Speedy Singhs]]'' and ''[[Thank You (2011 film)|Thank You]]'' in 2011.{{cite web|last=Khan|first=Maz|title=INTERVIEW: IISUPERWOMANII|url=http://www.mtv.co.uk/music/urban/12077-interview-iisuperwomanii| publisher=[[MTV (UK and Ireland)|MTV]]|accessdate=30 June 2014}} In 2014, Singh appeared in a small role in the 2014 Indo-Canadian production ''[[Dr. Cabbie]]''. In 2016, she voiced miniature unicorns named Bubbles and Misty in the animated film ''[[Ice Age: Collision Course]]'' and played a cameo role in the movie ''[[Bad Moms]]''. She made an appearance in the [[Disney Channel]] series ''[[Bizaardvark]]'' as herself. She also had several of her own web series with I Love Makeup channel on YouTube, including Giving Back Glam, The Tube's Hautest, and Lana Steele: Makeup Spy. Singh was cast in [[HBO]]'s [[Fahrenheit 451 (2018 film)|film adaptation]] of ''[[Fahrenheit 451]]'' after recording an audition outside an Internet cafe in Melbourne, Australia. She was in the region to promote her book and rushed the audition at her agent's urging around 2 a.m. in May 2017.{{Cite web|url=http://nationalpost.com/pmn/entertainment-pmn/lilly-singh-gets-role-in-hbo-reworking-of-ray-bradburys-fahrenheit-451/wcm/dd8b063f-625e-41e9-a7b8-c1f2e10e376e|title=Lilly Singh gets role in HBO reworking of Ray Bradbury's 'Fahrenheit 451'|last=Friend|first=David|date=19 June 2017|website=National Post/The Canadian Press|access-date=27 June 2017}} She plays the character of Raven, "a tabloid blogger who works with the fire department to spread the ministry's propaganda by broadcasting their book-burning raids to fans." {{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2017/tv/news/fahrenheit-451-movie-hbo-lilly-singh-1202469214/|title='Fahrenheit 451' HBO Movie Casts Digital Star Lilly Singh|last=Wagmeister|first=Elizabeth|date=16 June 2017|work=Variety|access-date=27 June 2017|language=en-US}} ===Live performances=== [[File: Lilly Singh.JPG|thumb|Lilly Singh (IISuperwomanII) performs at the Warfield in San Francisco during her world tour, "A Trip to Unicorn Island".]] In March 2015, Singh began a world tour called "A Trip to Unicorn Island", adapting her YouTube content and including singing, dancing, music performances, comedy, and her parent characters.{{cite web|url=http://www.torontosun.com/2015/05/15/superwoman-lilly-singh-readies-her-first-world-tour|title=Superwoman Lilly Singh readies her first world tour|work=Toronto Sun|accessdate=9 November 2015}} Her tour covered India, Australia, Hong Kong, Singapore, Dubai, Canada, Trinidad and Tobago, the United Kingdom and the United States. She documented the tour in her first feature movie, ''[[A Trip to Unicorn Island]]'', which also describes how YouTube fame is affecting her life. The movie was released on 10 February 2016 on YouTube Red.{{cite web| url=http://www.ew.com/article/2015/07/24/lilly-singh-trip-to-unicorn-island-teaser|title=Lilly Singh: A Trip to Unicorn Isle and teaser released - EW.com|work=ew.com|accessdate=9 November 2015}} She describes the film as being very "raw and genuine".{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2016/02/09/lilly-singh-trip-to-unicorn-island-interview|title=Lilly Singh admits the hardest part of filming 'A Trip to Unicorn Island'|website=Entertainment Weekly's EW.com|access-date=8 March 2016}} Her first book, ''How to Be a Bawse: A Guide to Conquering Life'', was released on 28 March 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailydot.com/upstream/lilly-singh-book-deal-bawse/|title=Lilly Singh to debut first book 'How to Be a Bawse' in 2017|date=27 July 2016|website=The Daily Dot|author1=Rae Votta|accessdate=27 July 2016}} ===Philanthropy=== In 2017, Lilly Singh was announced as a [[List of UNICEF Goodwill Ambassadors|UNICEF Goodwill Ambassador]], to advocate for children's rights. She has led a campaign called "GirlLove", promoting girls to end girl-on-girl hate. With this, she created a "GirlLove" rafiki bracelet with the brand [[Me to We|ME to WE]], and has helped around a thousand of girls to gain education {{Cite news|url=https://www.unicef.org/media/media_96640.html|title=UNICEF Goodwill Ambassador|work=UNICEF Press Release|access-date=21 July 2017|language=en}} In July 2018, Lilly traveled to South Africa as a UNICEF Goodwill Ambassador to meet the students of elementary schools who are speaking against [[bullying]] and classroom violence.{{Cite news|url=https://www.looktothestars.org/news/18149-lilly-singh-visits-south-africa-to-meet-students-affected-by-violence-in-school|title=Lilly Singh Visits South Africa To Meet Students Affected By Violence In School|date=2018-07-26|work=Look to the Stars|access-date=2018-08-07|language=en}} ===Accolades=== In 2014, her channel ranked at #39 on [[New Media Rockstars]] Top 100 Channels.{{cite web|url=http://newmediarockstars.com/2014/12/the-nmr-top-100-youtube-channels-50-26/|title=The NMR Top 100 YouTube Channels: 50-26!|website=New Media Rockstars|accessdate=6 January 2015}} The same year, she was nominated for a Shorty Award and a Streamy Award. In September 2015, ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'' magazine included Singh on their annual "Ones to Watch" list.{{cite web|title=Their Stars Are Rising: Meet PEOPLE's 2015 Ones to Watch!|url=http://www.people.com/people/gallery/0,,20952900_30388187,00.html#30388213|date=16 September 2015|accessdate=15 December 2015|website=People.com| publisher=Time Inc.}} Lilly received her first MTV Fandom Award, was nominated for two Teen Choice Awards, and won her first Streamy Award later that year. In October 2016, she ranked 8th on ''Forbes''{{'}} list of World's Top-Earning YouTube Stars of 2015.{{cite web|last1=Berg|first1=Madeline|title=The World's Highest-Paid YouTube Stars 2015|url=https://www.forbes.com/pictures/gjdm45jih/8-tie-lilly-singh-2-5-mi/|website=[[Forbes]]| accessdate=16 October 2015|date=15 October 2015}} She was also featured in Fast Company Magazine as the 100 Most Creative People in Business.{{cite web|title=Lilly Singh's Road Map For Building A Brand Beyond YouTube|url=http://www.fastcompany.com/3058985/most-creative-people/lilly-singhs-road-map-for-building-a-brand-beyond-youtube|author=Nicole Laporte|date=16 May 2016|website=fastcompany.com|publisher=Fast Company & Inc}} ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' magazine recognized her as one of their ''10 Comics to Watch'' for 2016, and she was honored at the Just For Laughs Film Festival in Montreal. In July 2016, she won two [[Teen Choice Awards]] from her three nominations. In January 2017, she won a [[People's Choice Award]] for Favorite YouTube Star. In September 2017, Singh won her fourth [[Streamy Award]]. In November 2017, Lilly Singh was also chosen as an ambassador for [[Pantene]] shampoo{{cite web|url=https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/vlogger-lilly-singh-now-pantene-ambassador-lifetime-growing-hair-finally-paid-off-174629771.html|last=Prinzivalli|first=Leah|title=Vlogger Lilly Singh is now a Pantene Ambassador: "A lifetime of growing my hair has finally paid off"|website=Yahoo|accessdate=13 January 2018|date=13 November 2017}} and partnered with [[Calvin Klein]].{{cite web|last1=Yotka|first1=Steff|title=There Are No Price Tags at Calvin Klein's Holiday Pop-Up|url=https://www.vogue.com/article/calvin-klein-amazon-fashion-pop-up-shop|work=Vogue|accessdate=13 January 2018|date=16 November 2017}} ==Filmography== {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" |- style="background:#ccc; text-align:center;" ! scope="column" | Year ! scope="column" | Film / Show ! scope="column" | Role ! scope="column" class="unsortable" | Notes |- | 2011–12 ! scope="row"| ''[[Law & Order Special Victims Unit]]'' | Kathrine | Episodes: "[[Scorched Earth (Law & Order: Special Victims Unit)|Scorched Earth]]"{{cite web|url=http://nbc.com/Law&OrderSpecialVictimsUnit|title=Law & Order Special Victims Unit: Scorched Earth|accessdate=21 September 2011}} & "[[Rhodium Nights]]"{{cite web|url=http://nbc.com/Law&OrderSpecialVictimsUnit|title=Law & Order Special Victims Unit: Rhodium Nights|accessdate=23 May 2012}} |- | 2014 ! scope="row"| ''[[Gulaab Gang]]'' | rowspan="3"| Herself | Playback singer and in song "Mauj Ki Malharein" |- | 2014 ! scope="row"| ''[[Dr. Cabbie]]'' | Inspired by her real life character |- | 2016 ! scope="row"| ''[[A Trip to Unicorn Island]]'' | Documentary |- | 2016 ! scope="row"| ''[[Ice Age: Collision Course]]'' | Bubbles/Misty | Voice role |- | 2016 ! scope="row"| ''[[Bad Moms]]'' | Cathy | Cameo |- | 2016 ! scope="row"| ''[[Life in Pieces]]'' | Amanda | Episode: [[List of Life in Pieces episodes#ep30|"Window Vanity Dress Grace"]] |- | 2017 ! scope="row"| ''[[Bizaardvark]]'' | Herself | Episode: "[[Bizaardvark#ep19|Paige's Birthday Is Gonna Be Great]]"{{cite web|url=http://tvlistings.zap2it.com/tv/bizaardvark-paiges-birthday-is-gonna-be-great/EP024192420019?aid=zap2it|title=Bizaardvark: Paige's Birthday Is Gonna Be Great|work=Zap2it|accessdate=12 December 2016}} |- |2017 ! scope="row"| ''[[F the Prom]]'' | Miss Fallsburg | Cameo {{Citation|last=Fine|first=Benny|title=F*&% the Prom|date=5 December 2017|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt5612742/|others=Danielle Campbell, Joel Courtney, Cameron Palatas|accessdate=26 December 2017}} |- |2017 ! scope="row"| ''[[Law & Order Special Victims Unit]]'' | Kathrine | Episode: "[[Law & Order: Special Victims Unit (season 18)#ep410|Sanctuary]]"{{cite web|url=http://nbc.com/Law&OrderSpecialVictimsUnit|title=Law & Order Special Victims Unit: Sanctuary|accessdate=27 May 2017}} |- | 2018 ! scope="row"| ''[[Fahrenheit 451 (2018 film)|Fahrenheit 451]]'' | Raven | Television film |- | 2018 ! scope="row" | ''[[Law & Order Special Victims Unit]]'' | Kathrine | Episode: "[[Law & Order: Special Victims Unit (season 20)| Man Up]]"{{cite web|url=http://nbc.com/Law&OrderSpecialVictimsUnit|title=Law & Order Special Victims Unit: Man Up|accessdate=27 September 2018}} & "[[Zero Tolerance]]"{{cite web|url=http://nbc.com/Law&OrderSpecialVictimsUnit|title=Law & Order Special Victims Unit: Zero Tolerance|accessdate=4 October 2018}} |- ==Awards and nominations== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year ! Award Show ! Category !
